Notes
This module has been developed as part of the new MSc Advanced Techniques in Biomedical Research.

Overview

Overview
This is the MSc Research Project Module. Students will work on a research project related to their specific allocated facility and technical expertise. Supervision will be provided by a staff members from Liverpool Shared Research Facilities (LIV-SRF) and/or an academic staff members from Faculty of Health and Life Sciences (FHLS) with relevant expertise. Projects are generally either lab, field or computer based (or a combination).

It is expected that the primary technique(s) (learned by the students in modules “Introduction to core facility methods, infrastructure and practice” and “Attaining competency in core facility practice and approaches”) will be the main technique(s) utilised in the project.

Students are expected to work independently, with guidance provided by their supervisor(s). Supervision will be provided by a members/managers of a research facilities or by academic staff members from FHLS. Dual supervision will be also possible (e.g. supervisory team involving member/manager of a research facility from LIV-SRF and academic staff member from FHLS). In this case the primary supervisor will be identified before the beginning of the project and will be responsible for project marking. The roles of both supervisors will be discussed and agreed before the beginning of the project.
Students will produce final report in the form of a manuscript that would be suitable for submission as a scientific publication (in the format of conventional research paper or technique-focused research paper). Relevant “Instructions for Authors” and examples of research papers published with the acceptable format will be provided to students before the beginning of the project.
Students will create a plan of work at the start of the project, and will present their work orally, as well as write a final project report. Students will also be assessed on their approach and technique during the project. This module will give students experience in conducting their own independent research project, and the presentation of this work through oral and written formats.

The module takes place at the end of the MSc programme i.e. in the summer semester (S3).
Educational Aims
To give students the opportunity to work in a guided, but independent, manner in an area of research related to expertise in advanced bioscience techniques attained in the prior modules BIOS771 and BIOS774.

To enhance and refine technical skills acquired in the technique-focused modules BIOS771 and BIOS774.

To provide training in research expertise including formulating hypotheses, planning of a research project, conducting experimental work, analysing research data, producing evidence-based conclusions, writing a research paper, presenting and discussing the findings of a research project.
Marketing Module Synopsis
In this 60-credit module, students will work on a research project in their chosen area of study in a research core facility (or in the laboratory of an experienced researcher - user or manager of said research core facility). Supervision will be provided by members/managers of research facilities and other experienced researchers from the Faculty of Health and Life Sciences.

Expanding from the introductory skills attained in BIOS771/774, students are expected to work independently, with guidance provided by their supervisor(s). Students are expected to create an experimental plan of work at the start of the project and then conduct the research. The approach is primary-research directed and connected with authentic assessments including approach and technique and presentation of research through both oral and written formats.

Students will create a plan of work at the start of the project, and will present their work orally, as well as write a final project report. Students will also be assessed on their approach and technique during the project. This module will give students experience in conducting their own independent research project, and the presentation of this work through oral and written formats.
Outline Syllabus
The syllabus covers an advanced laboratory project in core research facilities in Life Sciences. Specific projects will expand on skills gained in BIOS771/774, utilising techniques and equipment in one of the 23 shared research facilities including genomics, metabolomics, proteomics, etc. Students will learn how to plan and conduct their own research project safely within that facility.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Lab work
Description: Laboratory / Practical work to support project.
Attendance Recorded: No

Direct Supervision
Description: Supervision during laboratory/practical work
Attendance Recorded: No

Tutorial
Description: Regular progress meetings with project supervisor
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Self-directed learning
Description: Independent study including background reading, project write-up.
Attendance Recorded: No

In a typical week, students will undertake 4-5 days per week of facilities based lab work and self-directed learning (reading papers, planning experiments, etc). This should undertake 300 hours of lab work and 200 hours of self-directed learning in total. Additional hours for meetings with supervisors (tutorial) and supervision would be no more than 100 in total.

Supervision and assessment will be provided by members/managers of Liverpool Shared Research Facilities (LIV-SRF) or by academic staff members from Faculty of Health and Life Sciences (FHLS). The members of LIV-SRF staff selected for these roles will have experience of teaching (including practical training) and supervision of equipment users. This experience will be largely transferable to teaching, training and supervision of MSc students. LIV-SRF staff will collaborate with the Module Organisers and the Programme Director to define attainment benchmarks for research projects associated with each of the facilities. Detailed Module Handbook will specify requirements for laboratory workbook and project dissertation. To ensure adherence to the Code of Practice on Assessment (CoPA), module organisers (experienced T&R staff members) will provide training to the LIV-SRF staff before the start of the module. This training will include detailed discussion of module aims, learning objectives and assessment strategies (including discussion/calibration of marking rubrics for individual assessments).

Liverpool curriculum framework addressed:
Authentic Assessment:
Students will be assessed on their competence in experimental research skills (via approach and technique), quality of the final project write-up (completed in the format of a research paper) and presentation/discussion of their results. These assessments are authentic because demonstrating competence in experimental research skills, ability to write research manuscripts and present/discuss the results of their experiments are likely to be required from graduates of the programme in their professional life.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Assessment is split into 3 components:

Assessment 1. Approach and technique
Worth 25%; will be based upon Approach and Technique. Progress in designing and conducting lab project within the core facility. It will adopt the format of a reflective portfolio, and includes the students' record book and is an assessment of the student's "approach and technique" and has therefore no word or size limit, or resit opportunity. Progress marked by supervisor of the core facility.

Assessment 2: Final report
Worth 60%; a written report based on the project report. This will be a written laboratory report including background literature, aims and experimental question(s), methods, results and discussion. The report should be done in the style of a published research article and have a word limit of 3000-4500 (~10-15 pages) excluding figures.

Assessment #3. Oral presentation
Worth 15%; will be a Slideware (eg. PowerPoint) presentation -15 minute presentation (12 minute presentation and 3 minutes questions) identifying purpose, experimental plan, methods, results and conclusions of research project. Presentations will be viewed, assessed and questioned on understanding, live in-person by supervisor and 2nd assessor. Other students on the programme will be invited to attend presentations.

Resit strategy: resit opportunity will be given for each assessment and will have the same format and content as the original assessment. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission. Pass mark is 50.

Further information about the assessments and the correspondence between individual assessments, skills and learning outcomes can be found in the section Assessments.

Liverpool curriculum framework addressed:
- Research-connected teaching. Students will be assessed on their approach and technique, and will create a final project write-up of their research project.
- Authentic Assessment. Students will write final project write-up, and will present their work orally.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes: Master's
 ReferenceOutcome 
 M1 Independently plan a piece of original scientific research, demonstrating the ability to formulate a research question and consider ethical, theoretical, and practical factors.
 M2 Design and conduct a coherent set of investigations to test a hypothesis, applying advanced research techniques and critically analysing data to draw evidence-based conclusions.
 M3 Communicate scientific research results and conclusions including analysis of advanced biosciences techniques and concepts of facilities management effectively to a scientific audience, whilst addressing critique from colleagues and peers.
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Research management: developing a research strategy, project planning and delivery, risk management, formulating questions, selecting literature, using primary / secondary / diverse sources, collecting and using data, applying research methods, applying ethics.
 S2 Self-management: readiness to accept responsibility (that is, leadership), flexibility, resilience, self-starting, initiative, integrity, willingness to take risks, appropriate assertiveness, time management, readiness to improve own performance based on feedback / reflective learning;

Returned the module for further development
The module has not been approved for the following reasons:

1. Pre-requisites. As well as mentioning these in the overview, they also need to be shown in the Requirements tab (pre-requisites section).

2. The recommended changes to the LOs have not been made…

"The learning outcomes are quite prescriptive and consequently restrictive.
for example M4 'deliver a clear and well-structured presentation......successfully defend your work in an oral examination'
this would make it difficult to alter the module assessments without re-writing the learning outcomes.
M5 'in the format of a manuscript' - additional bracketed information not needed. This detail can be specified in the assessment strategy

Module leads should consider making the learning more transferrable in terms of what the student will be able to do at the end of the module e.g refer to communication generally or the ability to produce a scientific report etc."

To provide training in research expertise including formulating hypotheses, planning of a research project, conducting experimental work, analysing research data, producing evidence-based conclusions, writing a research paper, presenting and discussing the findings of a research project.
Marketing Module Synopsis
In this 60-credit module, students will work on a research project in their chosen area of study in a research core facility (or in the laboratory of an experienced researcher - user or manager of said research core facility). Supervision will be provided by members/managers of research facilities and other experienced researchers from the Faculty of Health and Life Sciences.

Expanding from the introductory skills attained in BIOS771/774, students are expected to work independently, with guidance provided by their supervisor(s). Students are expected to create an experimental plan of work at the start of the project and then conduct the research. The approach is primary-research directed and connected with authentic assessments including approach and technique and presentation of research through both oral and written formats.

Students will create a plan of work at the start of the project, and will present their work orally, as well as write a final project report. Students will also be assessed on their approach and technique during the project. This module will give students experience in conducting their own independent research project, and the presentation of this work through oral and written formats.
Outline Syllabus
The syllabus covers an advanced laboratory project in core research facilities in Life Sciences. Specific projects will expand on skills gained in BIOS771/774, utilising techniques and equipment in one of the 23 shared research facilities including genomics, metabolomics, proteomics, etc. Students will learn how to plan and conduct their own research project safely within that facility.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Lab work
Description: Laboratory / Practical work to support project.
Attendance Recorded: No

Direct Supervision
Description: Supervision during laboratory/practical work
Attendance Recorded: No

Tutorial
Description: Regular progress meetings with project supervisor
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Self-directed learning
Description: Independent study including background reading, project write-up.
Attendance Recorded: No

In a typical week, students will undertake 4-5 days per week of facilities based lab work and self-directed learning (reading papers, planning experiments, etc). This should undertake 300 hours of lab work and 200 hours of self-directed learning in total. Additional hours for meetings with supervisors (tutorial) and supervision would be no more than 100 in total.

Supervision and assessment will be provided by members/managers of Liverpool Shared Research Facilities (LIV-SRF) or by academic staff members from Faculty of Health and Life Sciences (FHLS). The members of LIV-SRF staff selected for these roles will have experience of teaching (including practical training) and supervision of equipment users. This experience will be largely transferable to teaching, training and supervision of MSc students. LIV-SRF staff will collaborate with the Module Organisers and the Programme Director to define attainment benchmarks for research projects associated with each of the facilities. Detailed Module Handbook will specify requirements for laboratory workbook and project dissertation. To ensure adherence to the Code of Practice on Assessment (CoPA), module organisers (experienced T&R staff members) will provide training to the LIV-SRF staff before the start of the module. This training will include detailed discussion of module aims, learning objectives and assessment strategies (including discussion/calibration of marking rubrics for individual assessments).

Liverpool curriculum framework addressed:
Authentic Assessment:
Students will be assessed on their competence in experimental research skills (via approach and technique), quality of the final project write-up (completed in the format of a research paper) and presentation/discussion of their results. These assessments are authentic because demonstrating competence in experimental research skills, ability to write research manuscripts and present/discuss the results of their experiments are likely to be required from graduates of the programme in their professional life.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Assessment is split into 3 components:

Assessment 1. Approach and technique
Worth 25%; will be based upon Approach and Technique. Progress in designing and conducting lab project within the core facility. It will adopt the format of a reflective portfolio, and includes the students' record book and is an assessment of the student's "approach and technique" and has therefore no word or size limit, or resit opportunity. Progress marked by supervisor of the core facility.

Assessment 2: Final report
Worth 60%; a written report based on the project report. This will be a written laboratory report including background literature, aims and experimental question(s), methods, results and discussion. The report should be done in the style of a published research article and have a word limit of 3000-4500 (~10-15 pages) excluding figures.

Assessment #3. Oral presentation
Worth 15%; will be a Slideware (eg. PowerPoint) presentation -15 minute presentation (12 minute presentation and 3 minutes questions) identifying purpose, experimental plan, methods, results and conclusions of research project. Presentations will be viewed, assessed and questioned on understanding, live in-person by supervisor and 2nd assessor. Other students on the programme will be invited to attend presentations.

Resit strategy: resit opportunity will be given for each assessment and will have the same format and content as the original assessment. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission. Pass mark is 50.

Further information about the assessments and the correspondence between individual assessments, skills and learning outcomes can be found in the section Assessments.

Liverpool curriculum framework addressed:
- Research-connected teaching. Students will be assessed on their approach and technique, and will create a final project write-up of their research project.
- Authentic Assessment. Students will write final project write-up, and will present their work orally.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes: Master's
 ReferenceOutcome 
 M1 Independently plan a piece of original scientific research, demonstrating the ability to formulate a research question and consider ethical, theoretical, and practical factors.
 M2 Design and conduct a coherent set of investigations to test a hypothesis, applying advanced research techniques and critically analysing data to draw evidence-based conclusions.
 M3 Communicate scientific research results and conclusions including analysis of advanced biosciences techniques and concepts of facilities management effectively to a scientific audience, whilst addressing critique from colleagues and peers.
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Research management: developing a research strategy, project planning and delivery, risk management, formulating questions, selecting literature, using primary / secondary / diverse sources, collecting and using data, applying research methods, applying ethics.
 S2 Self-management: readiness to accept responsibility (that is, leadership), flexibility, resilience, self-starting, initiative, integrity, willingness to take risks, appropriate assertiveness, time management, readiness to improve own performance based on feedback / reflective learning;

Notes
This module has been developed as part of the new MSc Advanced Techniques in Biomedical Research.

Overview

Overview
This is the MSc Research Project Module. Students will work on a research project related to their specific allocated facility and technical expertise. Supervision will be provided by a staff members from Liverpool Shared Research Facilities (LIV-SRF) and/or an academic staff members from Faculty of Health and Life Sciences (FHLS) with relevant expertise. Projects are generally either lab, field or computer based (or a combination).

It is expected that the primary technique(s) (learned by the students in modules “Introduction to core facility methods, infrastructure and practice” and “Attaining competency in core facility practice and approaches”) will be the main technique(s) utilised in the project.

Students are expected to work independently, with guidance provided by their supervisor(s). Supervision will be provided by a members/managers of a research facilities or by academic staff members from FHLS. Dual supervision will be also possible (e.g. supervisory team involving member/manager of a research facility from LIV-SRF and academic staff member from FHLS). In this case the primary supervisor will be identified before the beginning of the project and will be responsible for project marking. The roles of both supervisors will be discussed and agreed before the beginning of the project.
Students will produce final report in the form of a manuscript that would be suitable for submission as a scientific publication (in the format of conventional research paper or technique-focused research paper). Relevant “Instructions for Authors” and examples of research papers published with the acceptable format will be provided to students before the beginning of the project.
Students will create a plan of work at the start of the project, and will present their work orally, as well as write a final project report. Students will also be assessed on their approach and technique during the project. This module will give students experience in conducting their own independent research project, and the presentation of this work through oral and written formats.

The module takes place at the end of the MSc programme i.e. in the summer semester (S3).
Educational Aims
To give students the opportunity to work in a guided, but independent, manner in an area of research related to expertise in advanced bioscience techniques attained in the prior modules BIOS771 and BIOS774.

To enhance and refine technical skills acquired in the technique-focused modules BIOS771 and BIOS774.

To provide training in research expertise including formulating hypotheses, planning of a research project, conducting experimental work, analysing research data, producing evidence-based conclusions, writing a research paper, presenting and discussing the findings of a research project.
Marketing Module Synopsis
In this 60-credit module, students will work on a research project in their chosen area of study in a research core facility (or in the laboratory of an experienced researcher - user or manager of said research core facility). Supervision will be provided by members/managers of research facilities and other experienced researchers from the Faculty of Health and Life Sciences.

Expanding from the introductory skills attained in BIOS771/774, students are expected to work independently, with guidance provided by their supervisor(s). Students are expected to create an experimental plan of work at the start of the project and then conduct the research. The approach is primary-research directed and connected with authentic assessments including approach and technique and presentation of research through both oral and written formats.

Students will create a plan of work at the start of the project, and will present their work orally, as well as write a final project report. Students will also be assessed on their approach and technique during the project. This module will give students experience in conducting their own independent research project, and the presentation of this work through oral and written formats.
Outline Syllabus
The syllabus covers an advanced laboratory project in core research facilities in Life Sciences. Specific projects will expand on skills gained in BIOS771/774, utilising techniques and equipment in one of the 23 shared research facilities including genomics, metabolomics, proteomics, etc. Students will learn how to plan and conduct their own research project safely within that facility.

Progress marked by supervisor of the core facility.

Assessment 2: Final report
Worth 60%; a written report based on the project report. This will be a written laboratory report including background literature, aims and experimental question(s), methods, results and discussion. The report should be done in the style of a published research article and have a word limit of 3000-4500 (~10-15 pages) excluding figures.

Assessment #3. Oral presentation
Worth 15%; will be a Slideware (eg. PowerPoint) presentation -15 minute presentation (12 minute presentation and 3 minutes questions) identifying purpose, experimental plan, methods, results and conclusions of research project. Presentations will be viewed, assessed and questioned on understanding, live in-person by supervisor and 2nd assessor. Other students on the programme will be invited to attend presentations.

Further information about the assessments and the correspondence between individual assessments, skills and learning outcomes can be found in the section Assessments.

Liverpool curriculum framework addressed:
- Research-connected teaching. Students will be assessed on their approach and technique, and will create a final project write-up of their research project.
- Authentic Assessment. Students will write final project write-up, and will present their work orally.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Deliveries

 LocationPeriod 
 
Liverpool campus

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes: Master's
 ReferenceOutcome 
 M1 Independently plan a piece of original scientific research, demonstrating the ability to formulate a research question and consider ethical, theoretical, and practical factors.
 M2 Design and conduct a coherent set of investigations to test a hypothesis, applying advanced research techniques and critically analysing data to draw evidence-based conclusions.
 M3 Communicate scientific research results and conclusions including analysis of advanced biosciences techniques and concepts of facilities management effectively to a scientific audience, whilst addressing critique from colleagues and peers.
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Research management: developing a research strategy, project planning and delivery, risk management, formulating questions, selecting literature, using primary / secondary / diverse sources, collecting and using data, applying research methods, applying ethics.
 S2 Self-management: readiness to accept responsibility (that is, leadership), flexibility, resilience, self-starting, initiative, integrity, willingness to take risks, appropriate assertiveness, time management, readiness to improve own performance based on feedback / reflective learning;

Requirements Overview
It is expected that the primary technique(s) learned by the students in modules “Introduction to core facility methods, infrastructure and practice” and “Attaining competency in core facility practice and approaches” will be the main technique(s) utilised in the project.

Notes
This module has been developed as part of the new MSc Advanced Techniques in Biomedical Research.

Overview

Overview
This is the MSc Research Project Module. Students will work on a research project related to their specific allocated facility and technical expertise. Supervision will be provided by a staff members from Liverpool Shared Research Facilities (LIV-SRF) and/or an academic staff members from Faculty of Health and Life Sciences (FHLS) with relevant expertise. Projects are generally either lab, field or computer based (or a combination).

It is expected that the primary technique(s) (learned by the students in modules “Introduction to core facility methods, infrastructure and practice” and “Attaining competency in core facility practice and approaches”) will be the main technique(s) utilised in the project.

Students are expected to work independently, with guidance provided by their supervisor(s). Supervision will be provided by a members/managers of a research facilities or by academic staff members from FHLS. Dual supervision will be also possible (e.g. supervisory team involving member/manager of a research facility from LIV-SRF and academic staff member from FHLS). In this case the primary supervisor will be identified before the beginning of the project and will be responsible for project marking. The roles of both supervisors will be discussed and agreed before the beginning of the project.
Students will produce final report in the form of a manuscript that would be suitable for submission as a scientific publication (in the format of conventional research paper or technique-focused research paper). Relevant “Instructions for Authors” and examples of research papers published with the acceptable format will be provided to students before the beginning of the project.
Students will create a plan of work at the start of the project, and will present their work orally, as well as write a final project report. Students will also be assessed on their approach and technique during the project. This module will give students experience in conducting their own independent research project, and the presentation of this work through oral and written formats.

The module takes place at the end of the MSc programme i.e. in the summer semester (S3).
Educational Aims
To give students the opportunity to work in a guided, but independent, manner in an area of research related to expertise in advanced bioscience techniques attained in the prior modules BIOS771 and BIOS774.

To enhance and refine technical skills acquired in the technique-focused modules BIOS771 and BIOS774.

To provide training in research expertise including formulating hypotheses, planning of a research project, conducting experimental work, analysing research data, producing evidence-based conclusions, writing a research paper, presenting and discussing the findings of a research project.
Marketing Module Synopsis
In this 60-credit module, students will work on a research project in their chosen area of study in a research core facility (or in the laboratory of an experienced researcher - user or manager of said research core facility). Supervision will be provided by members/managers of research facilities and other experienced researchers from the Faculty of Health and Life Sciences.

Expanding from the introductory skills attained in BIOS771/774, students are expected to work independently, with guidance provided by their supervisor(s). Students are expected to create an experimental plan of work at the start of the project and then conduct the research. The approach is primary-research directed and connected with authentic assessments including approach and technique and presentation of research through both oral and written formats.

Students will create a plan of work at the start of the project, and will present their work orally, as well as write a final project report. Students will also be assessed on their approach and technique during the project. This module will give students experience in conducting their own independent research project, and the presentation of this work through oral and written formats.
Outline Syllabus
The syllabus covers an advanced laboratory project in core research facilities in Life Sciences. Specific projects will expand on skills gained in BIOS771/774, utilising techniques and equipment in one of the 23 shared research facilities including genomics, metabolomics, proteomics, etc. Students will learn how to plan and conduct their own research project safely within that facility.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Lab work
Description: Laboratory / Practical work to support project.
Attendance Recorded: No

Direct Supervision
Description: Supervision during laboratory/practical work
Attendance Recorded: No

Tutorial
Description: Regular progress meetings with project supervisor
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Self-directed learning
Description: Independent study including background reading, project write-up.
Attendance Recorded: No

In a typical week, students will undertake 4-5 days per week of facilities based lab work and self-directed learning (reading papers, planning experiments, etc). This should undertake 300 hours of lab work and 200 hours of self-directed learning in total. Additional hours for meetings with supervisors (tutorial) and supervision would be no more than 100 in total.

Supervision and assessment will be provided by members/managers of Liverpool Shared Research Facilities (LIV-SRF) or by academic staff members from Faculty of Health and Life Sciences (FHLS). The members of LIV-SRF staff selected for these roles will have experience of teaching (including practical training) and supervision of equipment users. This experience will be largely transferable to teaching, training and supervision of MSc students. LIV-SRF staff will collaborate with the Module Organisers and the Programme Director to define attainment benchmarks for research projects associated with each of the facilities. Detailed Module Handbook will specify requirements for laboratory workbook and project dissertation. To ensure adherence to the Code of Practice on Assessment (CoPA), module organisers (experienced T&R staff members) will provide training to the LIV-SRF staff before the start of the module. This training will include detailed discussion of module aims, learning objectives and assessment strategies (including discussion/calibration of marking rubrics for individual assessments).

Liverpool curriculum framework addressed:
Authentic Assessment:
Students will be assessed on their competence in experimental research skills (via approach and technique), quality of the final project write-up (completed in the format of a research paper) and presentation/discussion of their results. These assessments are authentic because demonstrating competence in experimental research skills, ability to write research manuscripts and present/discuss the results of their experiments are likely to be required from graduates of the programme in their professional life.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Assessment is split into 3 components:

Assessment 1. Approach and technique
Worth 25%; will be based upon Approach and Technique. Progress in designing and conducting lab project within the core facility. It will adopt the format of a reflective portfolio, and includes the students' record book and is an assessment of the student's "approach and technique" and has therefore no word or size limit, or resit opportunity. Progress marked by supervisor of the core facility.

Assessment 2: Final report
Worth 60%; a written report based on the project report. This will be a written laboratory report including background literature, aims and experimental question(s), methods, results and discussion. The report should be done in the style of a published research article and have a word limit of 3000-4500 (~10-15 pages) excluding figures.

Assessment #3. Oral presentation
Worth 15%; will be a Slideware (eg. PowerPoint) presentation -15 minute presentation (12 minute presentation and 3 minutes questions) identifying purpose, experimental plan, methods, results and conclusions of research project. Presentations will be viewed, assessed and questioned on understanding, live in-person by supervisor and 2nd assessor. Other students on the programme will be invited to attend presentations.

Resit strategy: resit opportunity will be given for each assessment and will have the same format and content as the original assessment. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission. Pass mark is 50.

Further information about the assessments and the correspondence between individual assessments, skills and learning outcomes can be found in the section Assessments.

Liverpool curriculum framework addressed:
- Research-connected teaching. Students will be assessed on their approach and technique, and will create a final project write-up of their research project.
- Authentic Assessment. Students will write final project write-up, and will present their work orally.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

 M3 Communicate scientific research results and conclusions including analysis of advanced biosciences techniques and concepts of facilities management effectively to a scientific audience, whilst addressing critique from colleagues and peers.

The module has not been approved for the following reasons:

1. Pre-requisites. As well as mentioning these in the overview, they also need to be shown in the Requirements tab (pre-requisites section).

2. The recommended changes to the LOs have not been made…

"The learning outcomes are quite prescriptive and consequently restrictive.
for example M4 'deliver a clear and well-structured presentation......successfully defend your work in an oral examination'
this would make it difficult to alter the module assessments without re-writing the learning outcomes.
M5 'in the format of a manuscript' - additional bracketed information not needed. This detail can be specified in the assessment strategy

Module leads should consider making the learning more transferrable in terms of what the student will be able to do at the end of the module e.g refer to communication generally or the ability to produce a scientific report etc."

Notes
This module has been developed as part of the new MSc Advanced Techniques in Biomedical Research.

Overview

Overview
This is the MSc Research Project Module. Students will work on a research project related to their specific allocated facility and technical expertise. Supervision will be provided by a staff members from Liverpool Shared Research Facilities (LIV-SRF) and/or an academic staff members from Faculty of Health and Life Sciences (FHLS) with relevant expertise. Projects are generally either lab, field or computer based (or a combination).

It is expected that the primary technique(s) (learned by the students in modules “Introduction to core facility methods, infrastructure and practice” and “Attaining competency in core facility practice and approaches”) will be the main technique(s) utilised in the project.

Students are expected to work independently, with guidance provided by their supervisor(s). Supervision will be provided by a members/managers of a research facilities or by academic staff members from FHLS. Dual supervision will be also possible (e.g. supervisory team involving member/manager of a research facility from LIV-SRF and academic staff member from FHLS). In this case the primary supervisor will be identified before the beginning of the project and will be responsible for project marking. The roles of both supervisors will be discussed and agreed before the beginning of the project.
Students will produce final report in the form of a manuscript that would be suitable for submission as a scientific publication (in the format of conventional research paper or technique-focused research paper). Relevant “Instructions for Authors” and examples of research papers published with the acceptable format will be provided to students before the beginning of the project.
Students will create a plan of work at the start of the project, and will present their work orally, as well as write a final project report. Students will also be assessed on their approach and technique during the project. This module will give students experience in conducting their own independent research project, and the presentation of this work through oral and written formats.

The module takes place at the end of the MSc programme i.e. in the summer semester (S3).
Educational Aims
To give students the opportunity to work in a guided, but independent, manner in an area of research related to expertise in advanced bioscience techniques attained in the prior modules BIOS771 and BIOS774.

To enhance and refine technical skills acquired in the technique-focused modules BIOS771 and BIOS774.

To provide training in research expertise including formulating hypotheses, planning of a research project, conducting experimental work, analysing research data, producing evidence-based conclusions, writing a research paper, presenting and discussing the findings of a research project.
Marketing Module Synopsis
In this 60-credit module, students will work on a research project in their chosen area of study in a research core facility (or in the laboratory of an experienced researcher - user or manager of said research core facility). Supervision will be provided by members/managers of research facilities and other experienced researchers from the Faculty of Health and Life Sciences.

Expanding from the introductory skills attained in BIOS771/774, students are expected to work independently, with guidance provided by their supervisor(s). Students are expected to create an experimental plan of work at the start of the project and then conduct the research. The approach is primary-research directed and connected with authentic assessments including approach and technique and presentation of research through both oral and written formats.

Students will create a plan of work at the start of the project, and will present their work orally, as well as write a final project report. Students will also be assessed on their approach and technique during the project. This module will give students experience in conducting their own independent research project, and the presentation of this work through oral and written formats.
Outline Syllabus
The syllabus covers an advanced laboratory project in core research facilities in Life Sciences. Specific projects will expand on skills gained in BIOS771/774, utilising techniques and equipment in one of the 23 shared research facilities including genomics, metabolomics, proteomics, etc. Students will learn how to plan and conduct their own research project safely within that facility.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Lab work
Description: Laboratory / Practical work to support project.
Attendance Recorded: No

Direct Supervision
Description: Supervision during laboratory/practical work
Attendance Recorded: No

Tutorial
Description: Regular progress meetings with project supervisor
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Self-directed learning
Description: Independent study including background reading, project write-up.
Attendance Recorded: No

In a typical week, students will undertake 4-5 days per week of facilities based lab work and self-directed learning (reading papers, planning experiments, etc). This should undertake 300 hours of lab work and 200 hours of self-directed learning in total. Additional hours for meetings with supervisors (tutorial) and supervision would be no more than 100 in total.

Supervision and assessment will be provided by members/managers of Liverpool Shared Research Facilities (LIV-SRF) or by academic staff members from Faculty of Health and Life Sciences (FHLS). The members of LIV-SRF staff selected for these roles will have experience of teaching (including practical training) and supervision of equipment users. This experience will be largely transferable to teaching, training and supervision of MSc students. LIV-SRF staff will collaborate with the Module Organisers and the Programme Director to define attainment benchmarks for research projects associated with each of the facilities. Detailed Module Handbook will specify requirements for laboratory workbook and project dissertation. To ensure adherence to the Code of Practice on Assessment (CoPA), module organisers (experienced T&R staff members) will provide training to the LIV-SRF staff before the start of the module. This training will include detailed discussion of module aims, learning objectives and assessment strategies (including discussion/calibration of marking rubrics for individual assessments).

Liverpool curriculum framework addressed:
Authentic Assessment:
Students will be assessed on their competence in experimental research skills (via approach and technique), quality of the final project write-up (completed in the format of a research paper) and presentation/discussion of their results. These assessments are authentic because demonstrating competence in experimental research skills, ability to write research manuscripts and present/discuss the results of their experiments are likely to be required from graduates of the programme in their professional life.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Assessment is split into 3 components:

Assessment 1. Approach and technique
Worth 25%; will be based upon Approach and Technique. Progress in designing and conducting lab project within the core facility. It will adopt the format of a reflective portfolio, and includes the students' record book and is an assessment of the student's "approach and technique" and has therefore no word or size limit, or resit opportunity. Progress marked by supervisor of the core facility.

Assessment 2: Final report
Worth 60%; a written report based on the project report. This will be a written laboratory report including background literature, aims and experimental question(s), methods, results and discussion. The report should be done in the style of a published research article and have a word limit of 3000-4500 (~10-15 pages) excluding figures.

Assessment #3. Oral presentation
Worth 15%; will be a Slideware (eg. PowerPoint) presentation -15 minute presentation (12 minute presentation and 3 minutes questions) identifying purpose, experimental plan, methods, results and conclusions of research project. Presentations will be viewed, assessed and questioned on understanding, live in-person by supervisor and 2nd assessor. Other students on the programme will be invited to attend presentations.

Resit strategy: resit opportunity will be given for each assessment and will have the same format and content as the original assessment. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission. Pass mark is 50.

Further information about the assessments and the correspondence between individual assessments, skills and learning outcomes can be found in the section Assessments.

Liverpool curriculum framework addressed:
- Research-connected teaching. Students will be assessed on their approach and technique, and will create a final project write-up of their research project.
- Authentic Assessment. Students will write final project write-up, and will present their work orally.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes: Master's
 ReferenceOutcome 
 M1 Independently plan a piece of original scientific research, demonstrating the ability to formulate a research question and consider ethical, theoretical, and practical factors.
 M2 Design and conduct a coherent set of investigations to test a hypothesis, applying advanced research techniques and critically analysing data to draw evidence-based conclusions.
 M3 Communicate scientific research results and conclusions including analysis of advanced biosciences techniques and concepts of facilities management effectively to a scientific audience, whilst addressing critique from colleagues and peers.
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Research management: developing a research strategy, project planning and delivery, risk management, formulating questions, selecting literature, using primary / secondary / diverse sources, collecting and using data, applying research methods, applying ethics.
 S2 Self-management: readiness to accept responsibility (that is, leadership), flexibility, resilience, self-starting, initiative, integrity, willingness to take risks, appropriate assertiveness, time management, readiness to improve own performance based on feedback / reflective learning;


Overview

Requirements Overview
It is expected that the primary technique(s) learned by the students in modules “Introduction to core facility methods, infrastructure and practice” and “Attaining competency in core facility practice and approaches” will be the main technique(s) utilised in the project.

BIOS773
Notes
This module has been developed as part of the new MSc Advanced Techniques in Biomedical Research.

Overview

Overview
This is the MSc Research Project Module. Students will work on a research project related to their specific allocated facility and technical expertise. Supervision will be provided by a staff members from Liverpool Shared Research Facilities (LIV-SRF) and/or an academic staff members from Faculty of Health and Life Sciences (FHLS) with relevant expertise. Projects are generally either lab, field or computer based (or a combination).

It is expected that the primary technique(s) (learned by the students in modules “Introduction to core facility methods, infrastructure and practice” and “Attaining competency in core facility practice and approaches”) will be the main technique(s) utilised in the project.

Students are expected to work independently, with guidance provided by their supervisor(s). Supervision will be provided by a members/managers of a research facilities or by academic staff members from FHLS. Dual supervision will be also possible (e.g. supervisory team involving member/manager of a research facility from LIV-SRF and academic staff member from FHLS). In this case the primary supervisor will be identified before the beginning of the project and will be responsible for project marking. The roles of both supervisors will be discussed and agreed before the beginning of the project.
Students will produce final report in the form of a manuscript that would be suitable for submission as a scientific publication (in the format of conventional research paper or technique-focused research paper). Relevant “Instructions for Authors” and examples of research papers published with the acceptable format will be provided to students before the beginning of the project.
Students will create a plan of work at the start of the project, and will present their work orally, as well as write a final project report. Students will also be assessed on their approach and technique during the project. This module will give students experience in conducting their own independent research project, and the presentation of this work through oral and written formats.

The module takes place at the end of the MSc programme i.e. in the summer semester (S3).
Educational Aims
To give students the opportunity to work in a guided, but independent, manner in an area of research related to expertise in advanced bioscience techniques attained in the prior modules BIOS771 and BIOS774.

To enhance and refine technical skills acquired in the technique-focused modules BIOS771 and BIOS774.

To provide training in research expertise including formulating hypotheses, planning of a research project, conducting experimental work, analysing research data, producing evidence-based conclusions, writing a research paper, presenting and discussing the findings of a research project.
Marketing Module Synopsis
In this 60-credit module, students will work on a research project in their chosen area of study in a research core facility (or in the laboratory of an experienced researcher - user or manager of said research core facility). Supervision will be provided by members/managers of research facilities and other experienced researchers from the Faculty of Health and Life Sciences.

Expanding from the introductory skills attained in BIOS771/774, students are expected to work independently, with guidance provided by their supervisor(s). Students are expected to create an experimental plan of work at the start of the project and then conduct the research. The approach is primary-research directed and connected with authentic assessments including approach and technique and presentation of research through both oral and written formats.

Students will create a plan of work at the start of the project, and will present their work orally, as well as write a final project report. Students will also be assessed on their approach and technique during the project. This module will give students experience in conducting their own independent research project, and the presentation of this work through oral and written formats.
Outline Syllabus
The syllabus covers an advanced laboratory project in core research facilities in Life Sciences. Specific projects will expand on skills gained in BIOS771/774, utilising techniques and equipment in one of the 23 shared research facilities including genomics, metabolomics, proteomics, etc. Students will learn how to plan and conduct their own research project safely within that facility.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Lab work
Description: Laboratory / Practical work to support project.
Attendance Recorded: No

Direct Supervision
Description: Supervision during laboratory/practical work
Attendance Recorded: No

Tutorial
Description: Regular progress meetings with project supervisor
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Self-directed learning
Description: Independent study including background reading, project write-up.
Attendance Recorded: No

In a typical week, students will undertake 4-5 days per week of facilities based lab work and self-directed learning (reading papers, planning experiments, etc). This should undertake 300 hours of lab work and 200 hours of self-directed learning in total. Additional hours for meetings with supervisors (tutorial) and supervision would be no more than 100 in total.

Supervision and assessment will be provided by members/managers of Liverpool Shared Research Facilities (LIV-SRF) or by academic staff members from Faculty of Health and Life Sciences (FHLS). The members of LIV-SRF staff selected for these roles will have experience of teaching (including practical training) and supervision of equipment users. This experience will be largely transferable to teaching, training and supervision of MSc students. LIV-SRF staff will collaborate with the Module Organisers and the Programme Director to define attainment benchmarks for research projects associated with each of the facilities. Detailed Module Handbook will specify requirements for laboratory workbook and project dissertation. To ensure adherence to the Code of Practice on Assessment (CoPA), module organisers (experienced T&R staff members) will provide training to the LIV-SRF staff before the start of the module. This training will include detailed discussion of module aims, learning objectives and assessment strategies (including discussion/calibration of marking rubrics for individual assessments).

Liverpool curriculum framework addressed:
Authentic Assessment:
Students will be assessed on their competence in experimental research skills (via approach and technique), quality of the final project write-up (completed in the format of a research paper) and presentation/discussion of their results. These assessments are authentic because demonstrating competence in experimental research skills, ability to write research manuscripts and present/discuss the results of their experiments are likely to be required from graduates of the programme in their professional life.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Assessment is split into 3 components:

Assessment 1. Approach and technique
Worth 25%; will be based upon Approach and Technique. Progress in designing and conducting lab project within the core facility. It will adopt the format of a reflective portfolio, and includes the students' record book and is an assessment of the student's "approach and technique" and has therefore no word or size limit, or resit opportunity. Progress marked by supervisor of the core facility.

Assessment 2: Final report
Worth 60%; a written report based on the project report. This will be a written laboratory report including background literature, aims and experimental question(s), methods, results and discussion. The report should be done in the style of a published research article and have a word limit of 3000-4500 (~10-15 pages) excluding figures.

Assessment #3. Oral presentation
Worth 15%; will be a Slideware (eg. PowerPoint) presentation -15 minute presentation (12 minute presentation and 3 minutes questions) identifying purpose, experimental plan, methods, results and conclusions of research project. Presentations will be viewed, assessed and questioned on understanding, live in-person by supervisor and 2nd assessor. Other students on the programme will be invited to attend presentations.

Resit strategy: resit opportunity will be given for each assessment and will have the same format and content as the original assessment. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission. Pass mark is 50.

Further information about the assessments and the correspondence between individual assessments, skills and learning outcomes can be found in the section Assessments.

Liverpool curriculum framework addressed:
- Research-connected teaching. Students will be assessed on their approach and technique, and will create a final project write-up of their research project.
- Authentic Assessment. Students will write final project write-up, and will present their work orally.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes: Master's
 ReferenceOutcome 
 M1 Independently plan a piece of original scientific research, demonstrating the ability to formulate a research question and consider ethical, theoretical, and practical factors.
 M2 Design and conduct a coherent set of investigations to test a hypothesis, applying advanced research techniques and critically analysing data to draw evidence-based conclusions.
 M3 Communicate scientific research results and conclusions including analysis of advanced biosciences techniques and concepts of facilities management effectively to a scientific audience, whilst addressing critique from colleagues and peers.
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Research management: developing a research strategy, project planning and delivery, risk management, formulating questions, selecting literature, using primary / secondary / diverse sources, collecting and using data, applying research methods, applying ethics.
 S2 Self-management: readiness to accept responsibility (that is, leadership), flexibility, resilience, self-starting, initiative, integrity, willingness to take risks, appropriate assertiveness, time management, readiness to improve own performance based on feedback / reflective learning;
